    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/originlogger/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-124970-_4lt92rr5muov"></a><strong>Executive Summary</strong></h2>
<p>On March 4, 2019, one of the most well-known keyloggers used by criminals, called <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-analyzing-various-layers-agentteslas-packing/">Agent Tesla</a>, closed up shop due to legal troubles. In the announcement message posted on the Agent Tesla Discord server, the keylogger’s developers suggested people switch over to a new keylogger: “If you want to see a powerful software like Agent Tesla, we would like to suggest you OriginLogger. OriginLogger is an AT-based software and has all the features.” OriginLogger is a variant of Agent Tesla. As such, the majority of tools and detections for Agent Tesla will still trigger on OriginLogger samples.</p>
<p>Recently, when sitting down to analyze some malware tagged as Agent Tesla, I was surprised to learn I was actually looking at something else. This fact revealed itself to me when I began analyzing the malware families’ configurations at scale after creating tooling to extract them.</p>
<p>In this blog, I will cover the OriginLogger keylogger malware, how it handles the string obfuscation for configuration variables and what I found when looking at the extracted configurations that allowed for better identification and further pivoting.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections from both OriginLogger and its predecessor malware Agent Tesla through <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr">Cortex XDR</a> and the <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall">Next-Generation Firewall</a> with <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/security-subscriptions">cloud-delivered security services</a> including <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/wildfire">WildFire</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-threat-prevention">Advanced Threat Prevention</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 74.5222%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 63.7736%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Related Unit 42 Topics</span></td>
<td style="width: 318.491%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/agenttesla/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Agent Tesla</span></a></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-124970-_t4ayo8qr0nc"></a><strong>OriginLogger Builder</strong></h2>
<p>When I began researching OriginLogger, I could find little to no public information about it. There are several Agent Tesla-related analysis blogs that I now recognize as pertaining to OriginLogger – sometimes tagged as “AgentTeslav3” – but otherwise, the public internet is pretty light on relevant information.</p>
<p>During my search, I stumbled across a <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o-MDujYrtto" rel="wpdevart_lightbox_video">YouTube video</a> posted in 2018 (before Agent Tesla closed up shop) by a person selling “fully undetectable” (FUD) tools. This person showed off the OriginLogger tools with a link to buy it from a known site that traffics in malware, exploits and the like.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124973" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124973" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124973 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-25.png" alt="OriginLogger feature highlights include: Powerful keyboard hook (detects all keybaord strokes. It does not work with the timer, it hook directly. Origin Logger has support all languages (Chinese, Greek, Latins Etc.); Web Panel (You can monitoring your logs on your hosting. We are providing our panel scripts and we can help you for installation); colored Log (Origin Logger saves logs in HTML colored texts make reading easier); Smart Logger (with this feature, the keylogger starts to work only in the windows where the words you specify are detected). " width="900" height="347" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124973" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. OriginLogger feature highlights (Source: screenshots of the OriginLogger sale page from a YouTube video on OriginLogger).</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_124975" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124975" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124975 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-26.png" alt="Full OriginLogger feature list includes the following: multilanguage support, 3 different delivery: PHP, SMTP and FTP, keylogger, colored log, screenshot logger, multi file binder, clipboard logger, smartlogger, password recovery, web panel, 7/24 support, fake message, autobuy, stable and fast, pure code, all windows OS supported, UAC bypass: WIN 7/8/10, assembly &amp; icon option" width="900" height="266" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124975" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. OriginLogger feature list.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Additionally, they showed both the web panel and the malware builder.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124977" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124977" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124977 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-27.png" alt="Screenshot of the Origin Logger web panel, with the &quot;keystrokes&quot; option selected. The panel shows where you can view and delete logs and includes info on Server Time, HWID, Machine Name, Log, IP Address. It offers actions including view/delete, copy, CSV, Excel, PDF and Print" width="900" height="310" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124977" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. OriginLogger web panel (Source: OriginLogger YouTube video).</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_124979" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124979" style="width: 500px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124979 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-28.png" alt="OriginLogger builder. The screenshot shots selections including Keyboard Logger (time), Clipboard Logger, Delete Backspaces, Smart Logger (which allows the user to input specific words such as facebook, twitter, gmail, etc.), Screenshot Logger (time)" width="500" height="452" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124979" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. OriginLogger builder.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The image of the builder shown in Figure 4 was particularly interesting to me as it provided a default string – <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">facebook, twitter, gmail, instagram, movie, skype, porn, hack, whatsapp, discord</span> – that might be unique to this application. Sure enough, a content search on VirusTotal shows one matching file (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/595a7ea981a3948c4f387a5a6af54a70a41dd604685c72cbd2a55880c2b702ed">595a7ea981a3948c4f387a5a6af54a70a41dd604685c72cbd2a55880c2b702ed</a></span>) uploaded on May 17, 2022.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124981" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124981" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124981 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-29.png" alt="Searching on VirusTotal for the string &quot;facebook, twitter, gmail, instagram, movie, skype, porn, hack, whatsapp, discord&quot; leads to the file SHA256: 595a7ea981a3948c4f387a5a6af54a70a41dd604685c72cbd2a55880c2b702ed as shown" width="900" height="164" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124981" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. VirusTotal search for string.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Downloading and attempting to run this file resulted in errors due to missing dependencies; however, knowing the builder’s filename, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">OriginLogger.exe</span>, allowed me to expand the search and locate a Zip archive (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/b22a0dd33d957f6da3f1cd9687b9b00d0ff2bdf02d28356c1462f3dbfb8708dd">b22a0dd33d957f6da3f1cd9687b9b00d0ff2bdf02d28356c1462f3dbfb8708dd</a></span>) containing all of the files required to run OriginLogger.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124983" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124983" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124983 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-30.png" alt="bundled files in the Zip archive include OriginLogger.exe, Updater.exe, NetCore.dll, Mono.Cecil.dll, settings.ini, eula.html, profile.origin" width="900" height="360" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124983" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Bundled files in Zip archive.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">settings.ini</span> file contains the configuration the builder will use, and in Figure 7 we can see the previous search string listed under <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SmartWords</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124985" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124985" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124985 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-31.png" alt="Settings.ini in OriginLogger includes logsettings such as Delivery, remember, keylogger, grabip, Log, ScreenLogger, screeninterval, Clipboard, Backspace, email, toemail, password, smtp, port, SSL, attach, ftphost, ftpuser, ftppassword, URL, UrlKey, istor, telegram_api, telegram_chatid, SmartLogger, SmartWords, smartLoggerType" width="900" height="824" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124985" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. OriginLogger Builder settings.ini file.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The file <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">profile.origin</span> contains the embedded username/password that a customer registers with when purchasing OriginLogger.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124987" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124987" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124987 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-32.png" alt="Screenshot of the OriginLogger builder login screen, including fields for email and password and option to remember password." width="900" height="587" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124987" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. OriginLogger builder login screen.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Amusingly, if you flip around the values in the profile file, the plaintext password is revealed.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124989" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124989" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124989 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-33.png" alt="Red arrows indicate which two values can be swapped in the profile.origin file to reveal the plaintext password. " width="900" height="19" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124989" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Contents of profile.origin file.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_124991" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124991" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124991 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-34.png" alt="Screenshot of the OriginLogger builder login screen, showing the results of flipping values in the file as shown in Figure 9. The threat actor's password is revealed in plaintext in the e-mail field, while the email is obfuscated in the password field. " width="900" height="586" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124991" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. OriginLogger builder login screen with threat actor password revealed in plaintext.</figcaption></figure>
<p>When a user logs in, the builder attempts to authenticate with the OriginLogger servers to validate the subscription.</p>
<p>At this point, I had two versions of the builder. The first one (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b22a0d*</span>), contained in the Zip file, was compiled Sept. 6, 2020. The other, which contained the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SmartWords</span> string (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">595a7e*</span>), was compiled on June 29, 2022, just about two years after the first.</p>
<p>The later version makes its authentication request over TCP/3345 to IP <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">23.106.223[.]46</span>. Since March 3, 2022, this IP has resolved to the domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">originpro[.]me</span>. This domain has resolved to the following IP addresses:</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">23.106.223[.]46<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">204.16.247[.]26<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">31.170.160[.]61</span></p>
<p>The second IP, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">204.16.247[.]26</span>, stands out due to resolving these other OriginLogger related domains:</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">originproducts[.]xyz<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">origindproducts[.]pw<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">originlogger[.]com</span></p>
<p>Things get more interesting when looking at the older builder. This one attempts to reach out to a different IP address for the authentication.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_124993" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124993" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124993 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-35.png" alt="The older version of OriginLogger reaches out to 74.118.138[.]76 for authentication as shown in the pcap" width="900" height="41" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124993" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. PCAP showing remote IP address.</figcaption></figure>Unlike the IP addresses associated with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">originpro[.]me, 74.118.138[.]76</span> does not resolve to any OriginLogger domains directly but instead resolves to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0xfd3[.]com</span>. Pivoting on this domain shows it contains both DNS MX and TXT records for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mail.originlogger[.]com</span>.</p>
<p>Beginning around March 7, 2022, the domain in question began resolving to IP <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">23.106.223[.]47</span>, which is one value higher in the last octet than the IP used for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">originpro[.]me</span>, which used 46.</p>
<p>These two IP addresses have shared multiple SSL certificates:</p>
<table style="width: 94.7343%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 25.1671%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">SHA1</span></td>
<td style="width: 25.0382%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Serial Number</span></td>
<td style="width: 27.9678%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Common Name</span></td>
<td style="width: 54.3363%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">IPs Observed</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 25.1671%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://community.riskiq.com/search/certificate/sha1?query=2dec9fdf91c3965960fecb28237b911a57a543e2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2dec9fdf91c3965960fecb28237b911a57a543e2</span></a></span></td>
<td style="width: 25.0382%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://community.riskiq.com/search/certificate/serialNumber?query=38041735159378560318847695768150611562"><span style="font-weight: 400;">38041735159378560318847695768150611562</span></a></span></td>
<td style="width: 27.9678%;"><a href="https://community.riskiq.com/search/certificate/subjectCommonName?query=WIN-4K804V6ADVQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;">WIN-4K804V6ADVQ</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 54.3363%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">23.106.223[.]46</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">23.106.223[.]47</span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 25.1671%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://community.riskiq.com/search/certificate/sha1?query=7a7e732229287c1d53a360e08201616179217117"><span style="font-weight: 400;">7a7e732229287c1d53a360e08201616179217117</span></a></span></td>
<td style="width: 25.0382%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://community.riskiq.com/search/certificate/serialNumber?query=133152806647474295963986900899009859692"><span style="font-weight: 400;">133152806647474295963986900899009859692</span></a></span></td>
<td style="width: 27.9678%;"><a href="https://community.riskiq.com/search/certificate/subjectCommonName?query=WIN-4K804V6ADVQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;">WIN-4K804V6ADVQ</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 54.3363%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">23.106.223[.]46</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">23.106.223[.]47</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">74.118.138[.]76</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">204.16.247[.]26</span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 25.1671%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://community.riskiq.com/search/certificate/sha1?query=3b3cf8039b779d93677273e09961203ffaac2d6f"><span style="font-weight: 400;">3b3cf8039b779d93677273e09961203ffaac2d6f</span></a></span></td>
<td style="width: 25.0382%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://community.riskiq.com/search/certificate/serialNumber?query=89480234209393487842197137895395039274"><span style="font-weight: 400;">89480234209393487842197137895395039274</span></a></span></td>
<td style="width: 27.9678%;"><a href="https://community.riskiq.com/search/certificate/subjectCommonName?query=WIN-4K804V6ADVQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;">WIN-4K804V6ADVQ</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 54.3363%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">23.106.223[.]46</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">23.106.223[.]47</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">74.118.138[.]76</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">204.16.247[.]26</span></span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Table 1. Shared SSL certificates.</em></span></p>
<p>The RDP login screens for both of the servers beginning with IP <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">23.106.223.X</span> show a Windows Server 2012 R2 server with multiple accounts.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_124995" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124995" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124995 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-36.png" alt="RDP login screen for 23.106.223[.]46 shows a Windows Server 2012 R2 server with multiple accounts - administrator, ftpuser and postgres" width="900" height="704" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124995" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. RDP login screen for 23.106.223[.]46.</figcaption></figure>When further searching for this domain, I came across the GitHub profile for user <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0xfd3</span>, which contains the two repositories shown in Figure 13.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124997" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124997" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124997 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-37.png" alt="The two GitHub repositories associated with user 0xfd shown in the screenshot are OutlookPasswordRecovery and Chrome-Password-Recovery" width="900" height="396" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124997" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. User 0xfd GitHub.</figcaption></figure>
<p>I’ll circle back to these later in the blog when looking at the code, but (spoiler alert) they are also used in OriginLogger.</p>
<h2><a id="post-124970-_nfzt2onxstmc"></a><strong>Dropper Lure</strong></h2>
<p>Before diving into the malware, I’ll quickly cover the dropper that led to the sample I set out to analyze. As both Agent Tesla and OriginLogger are commercialized keyloggers, the initial droppers will vary greatly between campaigns and should not be considered unique to either. I present the below as a real-world example of an attack dropping OriginLogger and show that they can be quite convoluted and obfuscated.</p>
<p>The initial lure document is a Microsoft Word file (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/ccc8d5aa5d1a682c20b0806948bf06d1b5d11961887df70c8902d2146c6d1481">ccc8d5aa5d1a682c20b0806948bf06d1b5d11961887df70c8902d2146c6d1481</a>).</span> When opened, this document displays a photo of a passport for a German citizen, along with a credit card. I’m not quite sure how enticing this would be as a lure for a normal user, but either way, you’ll note the inclusion of numerous Excel Worksheets below the image, as shown in Figure 14.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124999" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124999" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124999 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image.jpeg" alt="The Microsoft Word document displays a photo of a passport for a German citizen, along with a credit card. Numerous Excel worksheets appear below the image. " width="900" height="692" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124999" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. Lure document.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Each of these sheets are contained in separate embedded Excel Workbooks and are exactly the same:</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dc8b81e2f3ea59735eb1887128720dab292f73dfc3a96b5bc50824c1201d97cf Microsoft_Excel_97-2003_Worksheet.xls<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dc8b81e2f3ea59735eb1887128720dab292f73dfc3a96b5bc50824c1201d97cf Microsoft_Excel_97-2003_Worksheet1.xls<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dc8b81e2f3ea59735eb1887128720dab292f73dfc3a96b5bc50824c1201d97cf Microsoft_Excel_97-2003_Worksheet10.xls<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dc8b81e2f3ea59735eb1887128720dab292f73dfc3a96b5bc50824c1201d97cf Microsoft_Excel_97-2003_Worksheet2.xls<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dc8b81e2f3ea59735eb1887128720dab292f73dfc3a96b5bc50824c1201d97cf Microsoft_Excel_97-2003_Worksheet3.xls<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dc8b81e2f3ea59735eb1887128720dab292f73dfc3a96b5bc50824c1201d97cf Microsoft_Excel_97-2003_Worksheet4.xls<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dc8b81e2f3ea59735eb1887128720dab292f73dfc3a96b5bc50824c1201d97cf Microsoft_Excel_97-2003_Worksheet5.xls<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dc8b81e2f3ea59735eb1887128720dab292f73dfc3a96b5bc50824c1201d97cf Microsoft_Excel_97-2003_Worksheet6.xls<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dc8b81e2f3ea59735eb1887128720dab292f73dfc3a96b5bc50824c1201d97cf Microsoft_Excel_97-2003_Worksheet7.xls<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dc8b81e2f3ea59735eb1887128720dab292f73dfc3a96b5bc50824c1201d97cf Microsoft_Excel_97-2003_Worksheet8.xls<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dc8b81e2f3ea59735eb1887128720dab292f73dfc3a96b5bc50824c1201d97cf Microsoft_Excel_97-2003_Worksheet9.xls</span></p>
<p>Within each Workbook is a singular macro that simply saves a command to execute at the following location:</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Users\Public\olapappinuggerman.js</span></p>
<figure id="attachment_125001" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125001" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125001 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-38.png" alt="Screenshot shows the macro contained within each Excel Workbook in the malicious Word document. This macro saves a command to execute at C:\Users\Public\olapappinuggerman.js" width="900" height="421" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125001" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 15. Excel VBA macro.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Once run, this will download and execute via <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1218/005/">MSHTA</a> the contents of the file at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://www.asianexportglass[.]shop/p/25.html</span>. A screenshot of the website is shown in Figure 16.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_125003" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125003" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125003 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-39.png" alt="A minimalist but legitimate-appearing website at hxxp://www.asianexportglass[.]shop" width="900" height="520" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125003" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 16. Website to appear legitimate.</figcaption></figure>This file contains an embedded obfuscated script in the middle of the document as a comment.</p>
<figure id="attachment_125005" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125005" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125005 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-40.png" alt="Hidden in a comment in the html of a legitimate-appearing website is an embedded obfuscated script. " width="900" height="268" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125005" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 17. Website hidden comment.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Unescaping the script reveals the code shown in Figure 18, which downloads the next payload from a BitBucket snippet (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://bitbucket[.]org/!api/2.0/snippets/12sds/pEEggp/8cb4e7aef7a46445b9885381da074c86ad0d01d6/files/snippet.txt</span>) and establishes persistence with a scheduled task named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">calsaasdendersw</span> that runs every 83 minutes and uses MSHTA again to execute the script contained within <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://www.coalminners[.]shop/p/25.html</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_125007" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125007" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125007 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-41.png" alt="The unescaped script shown downloads the next payload from a BitBucket snippet and establishes persistence with a scheduled task that runs every minutes and uses MSHTA to execute a script. " width="900" height="214" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125007" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 18. Unescaped script.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The snippet hosted on the BitBucket website contains further obfuscated PowerShell code and two binaries encoded and compressed.</p>
<p>The first of the two files (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">23fcaad34d06f748452d04b003b78eb701c1ab9bf2dd5503cf75ac0387f4e4f8</span>) is a C# reflective loader using <a href="https://github.com/NYAN-x-CAT/CSharp-RunPE/blob/master/RunPE/RunPE.cs">CSharp-RunPE</a>. This tool is used to hollow out a process and inject another executable inside of it; in this case, the keylogger payload will be placed inside the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">aspnet_compiler.exe</span> process.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_125009" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125009" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125009 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-42.png" alt="PowerShell command. The command shown begins with [Reflection.Assembly]" width="900" height="52" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125009" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 19. PowerShell command to execute method contained in dotNet assembly.</figcaption></figure>Note the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">projFUD.PA</span> class that the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Execute</span> method is called from. Morphisec released a blog in 2021 called “<a href="https://blog.morphisec.com/revealing-the-snip3-crypter-a-highly-evasive-rat-loader">Revealing the Snip3 Crypter, a highly evasive RAT loader</a>,” where they analyze a crypter-as-a-service and fingerprint the crypter’s author using this artifact.</p>
<p>The second of the two files (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cddca3371378d545e5e4c032951db0e000e2dfc901b5a5e390679adc524e7d9c</span>) is the OriginLogger payload.</p>
<h2><a id="post-124970-_wyj93c55p5j8"></a><strong>OriginLogger Configuration</strong></h2>
<p>As previously stated, the original intention of this analysis was to automate and extract configuration-related details from the keylogger. To achieve this, I started by looking at how the configuration-related strings are used.</p>
<p>I won’t be diving into any of the actual functionality of the malware as it’s fairly standard and mirrors analysis of older Agent Tesla variants. Just as the threat actors’ advertisements state, the malware uses tried and true methods and includes the ability to keylog, steal credentials, take screenshots, download additional payloads, upload your data in a myriad of ways and attempt to avoid detection.</p>
<p>To start extracting configuration-related details, I needed to figure out how the user-supplied data is stored in the malware; it turned out to be straightforward. The builder will take the dynamic string values and concatenate them into a giant blob of text which is then encoded and stored in a byte array to be decoded at runtime. Once the malware runs and hits a particular function that needs a string, such as the HTTP address to upload screenshots to, it will pass the offset and string length to a function that will then carve out the text at that location within the blob.</p>
<p>To illustrate, below you can see the decoding logic used for the main blob of text.</p>
<figure id="attachment_125011" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125011" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125011 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-43.png" alt="The decoding logic used for OriginLogger's main blob of text. " width="900" height="57" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125011" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 20. OriginLogger plaintext blob decoding.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Each byte is XOR’d by the index of the byte within the byte array, and again XOR’d by the value <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">170</span> to reveal the plaintext.</p>
<p>For each sample generated by the builder, this blob of text will differ depending on what’s configured, so offsets and positioning will change. Looking at the raw text shown in Figure 21 is helpful, but without splicing it up, it becomes hard to determine where the boundaries end or begin.</p>
<figure id="attachment_125013" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125013" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125013 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-44.png" alt="Raw plaintext blog used by OriginLogger to store user-supplied data. " width="900" height="388" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125013" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 21. Plaintext blob.</figcaption></figure>
<p>It also does not help when it comes time to analyze the malware, as you won’t be able to discern when or where something is used. To figure this next piece out, I needed to look at how OriginLogger handles the splicing.</p>
<p>Below you can see the function responsible for carving out the string, followed by the beginning of the individual methods containing the offset and length.</p>
<figure id="attachment_125015" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125015" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125015 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-45.png" alt="The screenshot shows the function responsible for carving out the string, followed by the beginning of the individual methods containing the offset and length. " width="900" height="722" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125015" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 22. OriginLogger string functions.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In this case, if the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">B()</span> method is called at some point by the malware, it will pass <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2, 2, 27</span> to the obfuscated nameless function at the top of the image. The first integer is used for the array index where the decoded string will be stored. The second (offset) and third (length) integers are then passed to the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetString</span> function to obtain the text. For this particular entry, the resulting value – <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;font color="#00b1ba"&gt;&lt;b&gt;[</span> – is used during the creation of the HTML page it uploads to display the stolen data.</p>
<p>Knowing how the string parsing works, I could then automate the extraction of these strings. To start, it helps to look at the underlying intermediate language (IL) assembly instructions.</p>
<figure id="attachment_125017" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125017" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125017 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-46.png" alt="The underlying OriginLogger IL assembly instructions reveal three ldc.i4.X instructions that create a framework that can then be used to match all of the corresponding functions in the binary for parsing" width="900" height="210" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125017" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 23. OriginLogger IL instructions for string function.</figcaption></figure>
<p>For each of these lookups, the structure of the function block will remain the same. At index 6-8 in Figure 23, you will see three <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ldc.i4.X</span> instructions where <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">X</span> dictates an integer value that will be pushed onto the stack before calling the previously described splicing function. This overall structure creates a framework that can then be used to match all of the corresponding functions in the binary for parsing.</p>
<p>Leveraging this, I wrote a script to identify the encoded byte array, determine the XOR values and then splice up the decoded blob in the same fashion the malware uses it. With this, you can scroll through the decoded strings and look for things of interest. Once something is identified, knowing the offset and subsequent function name, you can pivot into the part of the malware that leverages them.</p>
<figure id="attachment_125019" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125019" style="width: 500px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125019 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-47.png" alt="Example of OriginLogger decoded strings. Includes Index, Offset, Count, etc. " width="500" height="549" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125019" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 24. OriginLogger decoded strings.</figcaption></figure>
<p>From here, I started renaming the obfuscated methods to reflect their actual values, which made analysis easier on the eyes.</p>
<figure id="attachment_125021" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125021" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125021 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-48.png" alt="Example of renaming obfuscated methods to reflect their actual values. " width="900" height="297" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125021" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 25. OriginLogger FTP upload function.</figcaption></figure>
<p>It should be noted that the same string deobfuscation can be achieved by using <a href="https://github.com/de4dot/de4dot">de4dot</a> and its dynamic string decryption feature by specifying the string types as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">delegate</span> and identifying the tokens of interest. This works extremely well for single file analysis.</p>
<p>Recall that I mentioned in the <a href="#post-124970-_t4ayo8qr0nc">OriginLogger Builder</a> section of this blog that I’d circle back to the GitHub repositories of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0xfd3</span> user. Take a look in Figure 26 at the Chrome Password Recovery code uploaded in March 2020 after OriginLogger took Agent Tesla’s prominence in the keylogger world.</p>
<figure id="attachment_125023" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125023" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125023 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-49.png" alt="Code from user 0xfd3's &quot;Chrome Password Recovery&quot; GitHub repository. Methods include: Chrome, Opera, Yandex, 360 Browser, Comodo Dragon, CoolNovo, SRWare Iron, Torch Browser and Brave Browser. " width="900" height="883" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125023" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 26. Chrome Password Recovery.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Compare Figure 26 to the code from the OriginLogger sample with renamed methods shown in Figure 27.</p>
<figure id="attachment_125025" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125025" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125025 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-50.png" alt="OriginLogger code with renamed methods, including: Opera, Comodo Dragon, Chrome, 360 Browser, Yandex, SRWare Iron, Torch Browser, Brave Browser, Iridium Browser, CoolNovo, 7Star, Epic Privacy Browser, Amigo, CentBrowser, CocCoc, Chedot, Elements Browser, Kometa, Sleipnir 6, Citrio. " width="900" height="350" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125025" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 27. OriginLogger Chrome password stealing function.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Look familiar? These types of similarities abound as OriginLogger has continued development where Agent Tesla left off.</p>
<h2><a id="post-124970-_50343o6a6han"></a><strong>Identifying OriginLogger Through Artifacts</strong></h2>
<p>Using this tooling, I extracted 1,917 different configurations, which gives insight into the exfiltration methods used and allows for clustering of samples based on the underlying infrastructure.</p>
<p>This is where I began to understand that what I was looking at wasn’t Agent Tesla but instead a different keylogger – OriginLogger. Two particular exfiltration methods that both showed multiple references to “origin” in some fashion led me to connect the dots.</p>
<p>For example, one of the URLs configured for a sample to upload keylogger and screenshot data to was <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://agusanplantation[.]com/new/new/inc/7a5c36cee88e6b.php</span>. This URL is no longer active so I started searching for historical information about it to understand what was on the receiving end of these HTTP POST requests. By plugging in the domain to <a href="https://urlscan.io/search/#agusanplantation.com">URLScan.io</a>, it showed login pages for the panel in the same directory but, more importantly, that the OriginLogger web panel (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c2a4cf56a675b913d8ee0cb2db3864d66990e940566f57cb97a9161bd262f271</span>) was observed on this host at the time of scanning four months ago.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_125027" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125027" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125027 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-51.png" alt="URLScan.io results for the agusanplantation[.]com domain includes an observation of the OriginLogger web panel. " width="900" height="539" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125027" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 28. URLScan.io scan history for domain.</figcaption></figure>Similarly, one of the exfiltration methods is through Telegram bots. To utilize them, OriginLogger requires a Telegram bot token to be included so the malware can interact with it. This provides another unique opportunity to analyze the infrastructure in use. In this case, I can use the token to query Telegram with what equates to a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">whoami</span> command and observe the names used by the bot creator. Below are a handful of examples showing relevant naming.</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">"id":2046248941,"is_bot":true,"first_name":"origin","username":"mailerdemon_bot"<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">"id":1731070785,"is_bot":true,"first_name":"@CodeOnce_bot","username":"PWORIGIN_bot"<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">"id":1644755040,"is_bot":true,"first_name":"ORIGINLOGGER","username":"softypaulbot"<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">"id":1620445910,"is_bot":true,"first_name":"ORIGINLOGS","username":"badboi450hbot"<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">"id":2081699912,"is_bot":true,"first_name":"Zara","username":"Zaraoriginbot"<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">"id":5054839999,"is_bot":true,"first_name":"Origin Poster","username":"origin_post_bot"</span></p>
<h2><a id="post-124970-_mp7t34vrsce6"></a><strong>Malicious Infrastructure</strong></h2>
<p>Like other keyloggers that are commercially sold, OriginLogger is used by a wide variety of people for various malicious purposes around the globe. In the past, I’ve written about taking a <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/keybase-threat-grows-despite-public-takedown-a-picture-is-worth-a-thousand-words/">deeper look at the victims of keyloggers</a> and what analyzing their screenshots can reveal about the potential intentions of the attackers. In this blog post, I will summarize some observations of the data extracted from the corpus of OriginLogger samples I collected. Most samples had multiple exfiltration techniques configured and I’ll cover each one below.</p>
<p><strong>SMTP</strong> is still the primary mechanism used for exfiltrating data and was identified in 1,909 samples. This is most likely because:</p>
<ul>
<li>The traffic will blend in with normal user traffic better than other included protocols.It’s relatively easy for attackers to obtain stolen e-mail accounts.</li>
<li>E-mail providers usually offer a large amount of storage space.</li>
</ul>
<p>There were 296 unique e-mail recipient addresses for the stolen data and 334 unique e-mail account credentials used to send them.</p>
<p><strong>FTP</strong> was configured in 1,888 samples using 56 unique FTP servers and 79 unique FTP accounts, with multiple accounts logging to different directories, likely based on different campaigns. Across the accessible servers, which were limited to 11 of the 56, there are 442 unique victims, with some victims being logged hundreds of times.</p>
<p><strong>Web uploads to the OriginLogger panel</strong> followed closely behind and were configured in 1,866 samples, uploading to 92 unique URLs. When analyzing these URLs, the PHP file used for the upload showed a pattern of alphanumeric characters in the filename, with a couple of additional patterns presenting themselves in the directory structure. Looking into the source code of the web panel as shown in Figure 29 shows that the PHP filename is an MD5 value of some random bytes and is placed in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/inc/</span> (incoming) directory.</p>
<figure id="attachment_125029" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125029" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-125029 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/word-image-52.png" alt="Source code for setup.php shows that the PHP filename is an MD5 value of some random bytes and is placed in the /inc/ directory. " width="900" height="294" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125029" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 29. OriginLogger source code for setup.php.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Keep in mind that many keylogger purchasers may not have much technical experience and tend to use a “full service” vendor that creates everything for them so that all they are required to do is distribute the keylogger. I suspect this is a reason for a lot of the URIs having similar structures. For example, the structure <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">http://&lt;ipaddress&gt;/&lt;name&gt;/inc/&lt;md5&gt;.php</span> is repeated throughout, and the first level of the directory shows values unlikely to be generated automatically – possibly account-related:</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b0ss/inc<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">rich/inc<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">divine/inc<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ma2on/inc<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">darl/inc<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">jboy/inc<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">newmoney/inc</span></p>
<p>Likewise, this directory structure changes the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">inc</span> to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mawa</span> and prepends <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">webpanel</span> to the name:</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">webpanel-roth/mawa<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">webpanel-qwerty/mawa<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">webpanel-dawn/mawa<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">webpanel-charles/mawa<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">webpanel-muti/mawa<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">webpanel-ghul/mawa<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">webpanel-reza/mawa</span></p>
<p>For the last exfiltration method, we have <strong>Telegram</strong> identified in 1,732 samples with 181 unique Telegram bots receiving the stolen data. In addition to being able to issue a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">whoami</span> for the bot, we’re able to query for information related to the channels where stolen information was uploaded. The most prominent of the channels are below with the details currently in use:</p>
<table style="width: 94.9997%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 8.30342%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Count</span></td>
<td style="width: 40.3261%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Channel Bio</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.4916%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Owner</span></td>
<td style="width: 43.4129%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Bot Name</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 8.30342%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">41</span></td>
<td style="width: 40.3261%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Invest in bitcoin now and attain financial freedom</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.4916%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Alaa Ahmed</span></td>
<td style="width: 43.4129%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">obomike_bot</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 8.30342%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">25</span></td>
<td style="width: 40.3261%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Free Cannabis </span></td>
<td style="width: 24.4916%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Cry_ptoSand</span></td>
<td style="width: 43.4129%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sales3w7_bot, oasisx_bot, valiat073_bot</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 8.30342%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">21</span></td>
<td style="width: 40.3261%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Atrium Investment Ltd: We Help You ACHIEVE YOUR LIFE GOALS</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.4916%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Doris E. Athey</span></td>
<td style="width: 43.4129%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Tino08Bot</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 8.30342%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">20</span></td>
<td style="width: 40.3261%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Self Discipline, Consistency and humanity.</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.4916%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Lucas Grayson</span></td>
<td style="width: 43.4129%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Odion2023bot</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 8.30342%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">18</span></td>
<td style="width: 40.3261%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Come Closer</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.4916%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anthony Forbes</span></td>
<td style="width: 43.4129%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Anthonyforbes2023bot</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 8.30342%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">14</span></td>
<td style="width: 40.3261%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Think it, Code It</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.4916%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">CodeOnce DeSpartan</span></td>
<td style="width: 43.4129%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">PWORIGIN_bot</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 8.30342%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">12</span></td>
<td style="width: 40.3261%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Dream cha$er 4L</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.4916%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Lurgard da Great</span></td>
<td style="width: 43.4129%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">johnwalkkerBot</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 8.30342%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">11</span></td>
<td style="width: 40.3261%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">coder..no system is safe.. Private crypt 100$..knowledge is power </span></td>
<td style="width: 24.4916%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">☠️The Devil☠️( do not disturb ))</span></td>
<td style="width: 43.4129%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Skiddoobot</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 8.30342%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">10</span></td>
<td style="width: 40.3261%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">PhD Engineering</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.4916%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Alexander Macbill</span></td>
<td style="width: 43.4129%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">swft_bot</span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Table 2. Prominent Channels</span></em></p>
<p>Finally, one feature that is not utilized very often is the ability for OriginLogger to download an additional payload after infecting the victim system. In the samples discussed here, only two were configured to download additional malware.</p>
<h2><a id="post-124970-_2an8ryq91inv"></a><strong>Conclusion</strong></h2>
<p>OriginLogger, much like its parent Agent Tesla, is a commoditized keylogger that shares many overlapping similarities and code, but it’s important to distinguish between the two for tracking and understanding. Commercial keyloggers have historically catered to less advanced attackers, but as illustrated in the initial lure document analyzed here, this does not make attackers any less capable of using multiple tools and services to obfuscate and make analysis more complicated. Commercial keyloggers should be treated with equal amounts of caution as would be used with any malware.</p>
<p>Luckily, in this instance, because of the similarities between the two aforementioned keyloggers, detections and protections carried over from one generation to the next – albeit with slightly inaccurate signature naming.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections from both OriginLogger and its predecessor malware Agent Tesla through <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr">Cortex XDR</a> and the <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall">Next-Generation Firewall</a> with <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/security-subscriptions">cloud-delivered security services</a> including <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/wildfire">WildFire</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-threat-prevention">Advanced Threat Prevention</a>.</p>
      
              </div>
              <!--<span class="post__date">Updated 5 June, 2024 at 10:53 AM PDT</span>-->

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="originlogger:related-resources:Crypted Hearts: Exposing the HeartCrypt Packer-as-a-Service Operation:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-12-13T23:00:21+00:00">December 13, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/packer-as-a-service-heartcrypt-malware/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="originlogger:related-resources:Crypted Hearts: Exposing the HeartCrypt Packer-as-a-Service Operation">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Crypted Hearts: Exposing the HeartCrypt Packer-as-a-Service Operation</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/redline-infostealer/" title="Redline infostealer" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="originlogger:related-resources:Crypted Hearts: Exposing the HeartCrypt Packer-as-a-Service Operation:Redline infostealer">Redline infostealer</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/lumma-stealer/" title="Lumma Stealer" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="originlogger:related-resources:Crypted Hearts: Exposing the HeartCrypt Packer-as-a-Service Operation:Lumma Stealer">Lumma Stealer</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/remcos/" title="Remcos" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="originlogger:related-resources:Crypted Hearts: Exposing the HeartCrypt Packer-as-a-Service Operation:Remcos">Remcos</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/packer-as-a-service-heartcrypt-malware/" title="Crypted Hearts: Exposing the HeartCrypt Packer-as-a-Service Operation" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="originlogger:related-resources:Crypted Hearts: Exposing the HeartCrypt Packer-as-a-Service Operation:read now">

                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>

              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/06_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of keylogger malware like KLogEXE and FPSpy. Person working on a laptop with lines of code displayed on the screen, with a blurred effect indicating motion or activity, surrounded by a vivid blue and red lighting." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/06_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/06_Malware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/06_Malware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/06_Malware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/06_Malware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="originlogger:related-resources:Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-09-26T10:00:51+00:00">September 26, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/kimsuky-new-keylogger-backdoor-variant/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="originlogger:related-resources:Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/mitre/" title="MITRE" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="originlogger:related-resources:Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy:MITRE">MITRE</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/keylogger/" title="Keylogger" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="originlogger:related-resources:Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy:Keylogger">Keylogger</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/north-korea/" title="North Korea" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="originlogger:related-resources:Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy:North Korea">North Korea</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">

                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of SnipBot. Digital abstract background featuring binary code and technology symbols with a blue glow in the shape of a skull." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="originlogger:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-09-23T21:00:55+00:00">September 23, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/snipbot-romcom-malware-variant/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="originlogger:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant">

                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">

                <div class="card-content__link">

<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			                 <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:400px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			                  <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:949px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

						</li>

							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/sase/ztna"   role="link" title="Zero Trust Network Access" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Network Security Platform:CLOUD DELIVERED SECURITY SERVICES:Advanced Threat Prevention:DNS Security:Data Loss Prevention:IoT Security:Next-Generation Firewalls:Hardware Firewalls:Strata Cloud Manager:SECURE ACCESS SERVICE EDGE:Prisma Access:Prisma SD-WAN:Autonomous Digital Experience Management:Cloud Access Security Broker:Zero Trust Network Access">Zero Trust Network Access</a>
						</li>    
					        
					</ul>
				</nav>

            <img class="pause" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/player-pause-icon1.svg" alt="Pause">
          </button>
          <button class="modal__minimize-btn is-minimized">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-minimize.svg" alt="Minimize">
          </button>
          <button class="modal__close"> 
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/close-modal.svg" alt="Close button">
          </button>
          <video class="modal__video" id="customVideo">
            <source src="" type="video/mp4">Your browser does not support the video tag.
          </video>
          <div class="modal__post-details" tabindex="-1">       
              <h3>Default Heading</h3>
              <a class="l-btn" href="#" title="Right Arrow Icon" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="overview:explore reports:View all reports">Read the article
              <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow">
              </a>
          </div>
          <div class="modal__video-controls">
            <div class="modal__video-seekbar input__wrapper"><span></span>
              <label class="is-hidden" for="modalSeekBar">Seekbar</label>
              <input class="custom-range" id="modalSeekBar" type="range" min="0" max="100" value="1">
              <p class="modal__remaining-time"></p>
            </div>
            <button class="modal__play-btn is-paused" id="playPauseBtn">
            <img class="play" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/player-play-icon.svg" alt="Play">
            <img class="pause" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/player-pause-icon1.svg" alt="Pause">
          </button>
            <div class="modal__volume-controls">
              <div class="modal__volume__wrapper">
                <button tabindex="0">
                  <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-volume.svg" alt="Volume">
                </button>
                <div class="modal__volume-seekbar"><span></span>
                  <label class="is-hidden" for="volumeBar">Volume</label>
                  <input class="volume__bar" id="volumeBar" type="range" min="0" max="1" step="0.1" value="0.7">
                </div>
              </div>
              <button class="modal__minimize-btn" id="minimizeBtn">
                <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-minimize.svg" alt="Minimize">
              </button>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div><!--  End: video modal -->

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.6.2' media='all' />

<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
});
</script>
